Award.AwardTitle: The Arctic Observing Network at Critical Gateways--A Sustained Observing System at Davis Strait
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: This award supports a further five years of ocean observations in Davis Strait between the west coast of Greenland and the east coast of Baffin Island, Canada. The Davis Strait observing array is part of the NSF Arctic Observing Network (AON), which supports long-term, science-driven observing that supports research into understanding rapid environmental system change in the Arctic. AON is a component of the broader Study of Environmental Arctic Change (SEARCH). The Davis Strait observing array employs a complementary system of moorings, autonomous gliders and ship-based hydrographic surveys to quantify, with robust error estimates, water mass variability, volume, liquid freshwater, heat and ice fluxes, ambient noise and marine mammal presence at weekly to inter-annual timescales, with biennial assessment of biogeochemical properties that integrate large-scale change. Successful completion of the award will extend the Davis Strait observational record to >10 years, which will complement similar records at Bering Strait and Fram Strait, the other main gateways between the Arctic Ocean and sub-Arctic seas. Long-term observing records of >10 years duration are required to quantify the cyclic variability and secular change in fluxes connecting the Arctic Ocean and sub-Arctic seas, and understand the role played by the Arctic and sub-Arctic in steering decadal scale climate variability. Hydrophones mounted on the moored array and gliders will document the presence of marine mammals. Concurrent environmental characterization provided by moorings, gliders and hydrographic sampling will allow marine mammal variability to be assessed in the context of environmental change.

Broader Impacts: The data obtained at Davis Strait are freely and openly available to the broader scientific community via a project Web site and at CADIS (Cooperative Arctic Data and Information Service), the AON data repository. A female graduate student will be responsible for data processing and quality control, generation of derived products and contributing to observing system design and optimization efforts. The project continues a collaboration with the Bedford Institute of Oceanography, Canada, and scientists and community members in Greenland. The Davis Strait observing array is being used as a test bed for polar ocean observing research and development and technology transfer to the broader ocean science community. In Seattle, the principal investigators will continue to participate in the Polar Science Weekend at the Pacific Science Center, Seattle, and collaborate with a high school vocational program. Whale sounds will be available to a broad audience via the Macauley Library of Natural Sounds at Cornell University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

            An observing system consisting of a mooring array, long-endurance autonomous gliders and annual (shifting to biennial in 2012) hydrographic sampling has quantified weekly to interannual variability in circulation, watermass structure and fluxes (volume, freshwater and heat), biogeochemistry and marine mammal presence at Davis Strait. Measurements began in 2004 and currently extend through autumn 2017. These complementary platforms: (1) resolve deformation-scale O (10 km) motions across the 300-km wide strait, (2) quantify temperature and salinity variability over the entire domain, including the critical but hazardous ice-ocean boundary layer and shallow shelves, (3) provide weekly resolution over multi-year timescales and (4) document changes in freshwater constituents and biogeochemistry.

            The Davis Strait projects have supported 34 published papers, with 1 currently under review, 3 doctoral dissertations and several reports. Beyond these, data from the Davis Strait gateway array and results from these 34 papers have been used as part of numerous published investigations and syntheses (such as the recent Arctic freshwater synthesis). PIs from the Davis Strait programs used observing system data for studies that include: (i) observational syntheses of the Arctic freshwater cycle, (ii) a review of circulation over the Canadian polar shelf, (iii) an assessment of the Arctic outflow’s impact on Labrador Sea deep convection (iv) an investigation of Arctic outflow acidification and (v) evaluations of Arctic numerical models. This project produced the first detailed analyses of measurements from the moored array, a study of fin whale behavior in Davis Strait, and supported grounbreaking developments autonomous glider operations with long-range acoustic navigation in ice-covered environments.

            The 2004-2013 monthly-mean net volume and freshwater flux shows significant interannual variability, with only a weak seasonal cycle (due to phase cancellations in the seasonal cycle of the watermass components that make up the net fluxes) and no statistically significant trends. The 2004-2013 mean net volume and freshwater fluxes are -1.6±0.2 Sv and -93±6 mSv, respectively, with sea ice contributing -10±1 mSv of freshwater flux. When analyzed by watermass class, volume and freshwater fluxes show seasonality in south-flowing Arctic waters with maxima in autumn and summer. The Davis Strait array also captured the 2009-2010 freshwater release from the Arctic that appeared as freshening of the Arctic watermass, but not as increased southward export of Arctic water, due to a compensating reduction in volume transport.

Broader Impacts

            The Davis Strait observing system is an element of an international array that aims to maintain climate-scale observations at the four gateways connecting the Arctic with the subpolar oceans, part of a broad network of sustained Arctic observing activities. Since its inception, the Davis Strait system has featured close collaboration with researchers at the Bedford Institute of Oceanography (BIO), who lead the project’s chemistry program, provide sensors for the moored array and contribute to system design and science. This collaboration has yielded enormous science benefit, including access to extensive historical data holdings, connections with ongoing research downstream and an active data analysis and modeling effort. The program has similar long-term ties with researchers at the Greenland Institute of Natural Resources (GINR). The collaboration includes successful joint mooring deployments in central Baffin Bay to support Greenlandic marine mammal studies, graduate student training, and collaborative data analysis.

            Davis Strait data are freely available through both the NSF Arctic Data Center and the dedicated project website.

            Davis Strait data contribute to other observing networks through the downstream impacts of Arctic discharge on lower-latitude observing systems. In addition to being a gateway component of the US Arctic Observing Network, the Davis Strait System is an element of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation Program (US AMOC) and constrains the northern boundary for the western component of the new international Overturning in the Subpolar North Atlantic (OSNAP) Program. The Davis Strait program has been a designated as Global Ocean Ship-Based Hydrographic Investigations Program (GO-SHIP) line, reflecting the value the science community places on sustained measurements across the gateway. The project is also part of the Global Ocean Acidification Observing Network (GOA-ON) and was used in Arctic Monitoring Assessment Programme, Arctic Ocean Acidification (AMAP-AOA) report, submitted to the Arctic Council in 2013.           

            Technologies developed for the Davis Strait program have been transferred to other teams and applied to a range of problems. IceCAT moorings (for sampling in ice-threatened environments) have been used in the Bering Sea, Chukchi Sea, Fram Strait and Labrador Sea. Ice-capable Seagliders have been used in Fram Strait, the Ross Sea polynya and for process studies of the marginal ice zone in the Beaufort Sea. The program has fueled advances subsequently incorporated into production Seagliders, include power management and conservation (50% endurance improvement), payload controllers, refinements to improve reliability and numerous advances in control and data handling.

            The Davis Strait program provided data for three PhD dissertations, and project cruises have been used to train diverse graduate and post-doctoral students.
